OREGON SENATE BILL 75, sponsored by State
Sen. Keith Burbidge, “requires employers to provide
rest periods for employes of not less than 10 minutes
for every 4 hours worked without deduction from ememployes’
Irreverent comment by employer: “How about a
companion bill to provide work periods of not less than
10 minutes for every 4 hours of rest by an employe?”

Oregon has become the 25th state to ratify
the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) to the
United States Constitution. The House of
Thursday by a vote of 50 to 9.
on the grounds of sex, and needs approval of
The floor debate over the ERA was the
longest and most heated of this session.
Seven of the 11 women representatives spoke
in favor of the amendment. Ail opposing
Norma Paulus, R-Salem, said she was
concerned about the way the government
looked at women. “The next time the
Supreme Court looks at the word ‘person’ it
will know that it includes me as a woman,"
Paulus also answered the charge that the
ERA would subject women to the draft: “1
can’t for the life of me see why my son’s duty
to the country is greater than that of my
Vera Katz, D-Portland, said that the ERA
was not to protect women, but to secure their
employment of women in occupations that
Grove, was a bit piqued when he noted that
many of the objections to ERA were “far
always been the biggest obstacle to human
the separate restroom issue: “my duty is to
talk about restrooms. I contacted four major
oil companies and asked them if the ERA
passes, would they build new filling stations
with just one restroom? After 1 convinced
them that 1 was serious they said no, they
Rep. Sidney Bazett, R-Grants Pass, was in
the opposition when he read a quotation
were made.by God to get rid of boredom. He
also said that if the ERA passed, the state
would have to pass 75 new laws.
also opposed to the ERA. “The ERA does
just the opposite of all the things we have
been so proud of. . . it promotes sameness
between the sexes and the states. 1 still prefer
to see the Mrs. and the wife taking the name
of the husband. That is the way America
became the way it is,” he said.

Nothing would make us happier than
to have both candidates for the House
from District 31 win. These are two
Norma Paulus, Salem lawyer, is a
one-term House member running in the
new district which includes part of the
Salem area. Jim Mead, Salem accpun-
tant, is the challenger. This is his first
We’ve known both for years, and resrespect
knows his issues and procedures well.
He’d learn fast and be productive before
Mrs. Paulus, 39, made a fast start last
session and would be one of the imporimportant
Mrs. Paulus is the Republican, and
Mead the Democrat. But Mrs. Paulus
probably is the more liberal of the two.
In the last session she was a leader in a
number of innovative social reforms that
tional standards. On the other hand
Mead sounds fairly cautious on such isissues,
sues, perhaps simply because he isn’t yet
sure of all ramifications. But he is on the
liberal side when compred with the statestatewide
We’ll give Mrs. Paulus our recommenrecommendation
dation on the basis of experience—and
hope that Mead, if he loses, tries again
when he can face a less impressive oppoopponent.
